column58: |replace linux rps setting with a smarter script
column60: we were setting receive packet steering as "ff" (i.e. all cpus, up to 16
column61: cpus) to all rx queues for a given interface (eth0). while is this what
column62: basically everyone on the web recommends, experience in the field has
column63: shown that this was very unbalanced, with cpu 0 getting most of the load
column64: and even spending all of its time being busy -and producing packet loss
column65: & latency- while other cpus remained relatively idle.
column67: a smarter way of handling the load is pinning each queue to a separate
column68: cpu, while isolating to the greatest extent the cpus for each. this has
column69: proven to balance the load as fairly as possible. experimentation has
column70: also shown that using hyperthreading siblings (even pairing them with
column71: each other) is actively worse and it's best to ignore them completely.
column73: finally, experimentation has shown that for our primary use case (lvs),
column74: transmit packet steering makes little to no difference.
column76: this replaces the older bash one-liner with a python script which tries
column77: to be extra smart about how to distribute queues to cpus (and cpus with
column78: ht). unfortunately, the number of cpus and queues can differ wildly
column79: between boxes and -in cases such as amslvs1- can unconvienently be five
column80: queues for four cpus, so we need to cover multiple cases.
column82: this has been tested manually on amslvs1 & lvs1001 and made a

column3: bacula can fail when trying to determine the correct key to use during
column4: decryption. this has been observed in precise, trusty and jessie but is
column5: not entirely deterministic. we have had quite a few successul restores
column6: in the past in production, but there have been failed ones as well. in
column7: testing, it has been reported to consistently fail. reversing the order
column8: of certificate and private key in the keypair file and setting the key
column9: first seems to solve the issue.

column25: introduce a mirrors::debian class that mirrors a debian ftp. this uses
column26: debian's official mirrors scripts, archvsync (aka ftpsync). include the
column27: class from the respective role class and while at it, add monitoring
column28: based on the preexisting ubuntu check_apt_mirror, which now takes a
column29: parameter. note that the mirror pulse for debian is set also every 6
column30: hours but 40' far apart from the ubuntu pulse as to avoid overlap
column31: between the two.
column33: it should be noted that instead of archvsync, debmirror was also
column34: explored. while debmirror was more well-documented and packaged, in the
column35: end it seemed more oriented to "local" mirrors and tried to be too smart
column36: in this regard. there were multiple occurences of this but the tipping
column37: point was when debmirror choked when "experimental" had failing
column38: checksums and ended up not syncing *any* suite.
column40: so, stick with archvsync, which while a bit crude will allow us to
column41: potentially become a (partial) official mirror.
column43: finally, the mirrors module in general could probably use some extra
column44: love as it's not very configurable right now and hardcodes a bunch of
column45: settings. it isn't /too/ bad and should do it for now, though.

column54: |make it possible for logmsgbot to report to more than one channel
column56: some conversations in #wikimedia-dev end up drifting over to
column57: announcements make #wikimedia-operations the natural place to coordinate
column58: mediawiki code deployments and their outcomes. logmsgbot isn't especially
column59: noisy, so perhaps the best solution is to have it log to both channels.
column60: this patch modifies the tcpircbot module to make it multi-channel-capable, and
column61: adds #wikimedia-dev to the list of channels logmsgbot should report to.
column63: includes a few small but unrelated touch-ups to the tcpircbot module.

column71: also parametrizes 'cidr' configuration option.
column74: |add 'tcpircbot' puppet class
column76: this puppet class configures a python script that listens on a tcp socket and
column77: forwards incoming data to an irc channel. it allows setting up automatic
column78: announcements to irc from machines in the cluster that do not have a public
column79: interface. the script runs as an upstart service. by default, it connects to
column80: freenode via ssl, and listens on port 9200 for messages to forward.
column82: sample configuration:
column96: if a "cidr" key is set, it is interpreted as an ipv6 cidr range. inbound
column97: connections from addresses outside this range are rejected. if "cidr" is not
column98: set, only private and loopback ip addresses are allowed to connect.

column3: we don't currently use ensure => absent for sudo::user or sudo::group
column4: anywhere yet, but it was broken (the template gets evaluated anyway and
column5: borks if there are no privileges defined) and needed fixing anyway.
column8: |sudo: actually make the linting safety checks work
column10: the current linting execs, shamelessly stolen from the admin module, had
column11: a logic error in which it tried doing "exit 0" as means to handle the
column12: ensure => absent case, but ended up doing it unconditionally, therefore
column15: there's two ways to fix this: either move the "test -e" check to a
column16: separate onlyif parameter, or guard the whole exec with an "if $ensure
column17: == present" check. the latter feels cleaner, so pick that one.
column19: change-id: i9b29d3e093446cbd602087d27718f6813cfe372b
column20: |sudo: port over linting & sudoers from admin::sudo
column22: admin::sudo pulls a nifty trick to lint bad sudoers values and
column23: self-heal, as to not let mistakes break sudo for the whole system. port
column24: it over to sudo::user & sudo::group. while at it, also cleanup our own
column25: sudoers file, basing it off the admin::sudo sudoers (and also fixing the
column26: undefined variable check).
column31: sudo::user has gained a few niceties that sudo::group hadn't, like
column32: comments and a $title_safe regexp, so port them over.
column37: the sudo module contains definitions to set up sudoers but class sudo is
column38: empty and nothing actually gurantees that package "sudo" is installed
column39: (other than ubuntu installing it by default).
column41: fix this by ensuring => present for package['sudo'].
column43: change-id: if3233ed70b4b4b232685f4db932e548ad1c48f56
column44: |allow multiple sudo::user grants for same user
column46: right now, the user receiving the sudo grant is specified via the resource
column47: title. since resource titles must be unique, only one grant may be declared per
column48: user. that's a stupid limitation, so let's fix it.

column6: |create a shim module for citoid around service::node
column8: this is a shim layer module for citoid around service::node. the idea is
column9: that in the future (or in other modules) we will end up with extra
column10: functionality needed in citoid (or other services) that should not
column11: however be provided by role classes or service::node. that functionality
column12: can be added in the service module in the main or some other class,
column13: making changes in the role class and the service module unneeded. that
column14: is a path however a path that should not be taken lightly as it is meant
column15: to be used to satisfy extra needs of services and not a way to diverge
column16: from the norm that the service module provides

column4: |apache2: rename apache2_test_config => apache2_test_config_and_restart
column6: the current name is misleading, because it does not communicate the fact that a
column7: successful config test will lead to an apache 2 restart.
column10: |apache module: test config before attempting restart
column12: in an ideal world we'd never deploy broken apache configs. but unfortunately
column13: sometimes we do. in such cases, attempting to restart apache causes the service
column14: to stop and then fail to start, which leaves us dead in the water. to avoid
column15: that, we should run 'apache2ctl configtest' before attempting a restart.
column17: we could add an onlyif => 'apache2ctl configtest' parameter to the
column18: exec['apache2_hard_restart'] resource, but the problem with that approach is
column19: that puppet will be silent about broken configs. the service won't be
column20: restarted, but there won't be any feedback for the deployer.
column22: so instead make it a separate exec resource that notifies the restart exec.
column23: this way, if configtest fails, puppet will fail loudly.
column25: also remove the status check from the apache2 restart exec. since it depends on
column26: the service (which is ensure => running) it must be true that apache is up.
column31: change-id: i2b487389858699d60a2dd70691ef5abab3d8b40b
column32: |apache: on service refresh, do a graceful reload instead of start/stop
column34: with this change, when puppet refreshes service['apache2'], it'll initiate a
column35: graceful reload rather than a full service stop / service start. a graceful
column36: reload allows open requests to terminate gracefully, and it performs a config
column37: check before shutting down, so it comes with the added benefit of not leaving
column38: the service dead in the water if you happen to deploy a config change with a
column41: change-id: id030fef0016fdc07076bb1d375e7b9b2c9c5229d

column3: systemd implements a two-stage lookup for unit files:
column4: /lib/systemd/system/foo.service is meant for distro-shipped units
column7: base::service_unit writes puppet-generated systemd units to
column8: /lib/systemd, because the "systemctl mask" command adds a symlink
column9: to /dev/null in /etc/systemd, which fails if we have a puppet-generated
column10: unit present. we need this functionality to allow service owners to
column11: prevent services from starting without disabling puppet entirely.
column13: on the other hand, this creates a problem for packages which ship
column14: a systemd unit as part of their debian package, but which we need
column15: to customise. in particular hhvm: it ships a native hhvm.service
column16: unit, but we're extending it heavily to apply site-specific resource
column17: limits, restart behaviour and handling of environment variables.
column18: that means that after an upgrade hhvm, is running with incorrect
column19: settings until the next puppet run.
column21: this patch provides support for passing an override file to
column22: base::service_unit; the settings made in override files amend /
column23: extend the ones provided by the debian package.
column25: there are some notable gotchas for override files:
column26: - dependencies cannot be overridden
column27: - to wipe an existing setting from a vendor file, it needs to be
column28: reset in the override with a blank line, e.g
column30: execstart=
column31: execstart=/bin/foo --daemon

column15: otherwise, hhvm would not be able to write to it.
column20: this patch adds two shell scripts i wrote based on my experience in t99525 and
column21: t820. the two scripts are designed to help isolate hhvm memory leaks. the
column22: first, `hhvm-collect-heaps`, enables jemalloc heap profiling and writes a heap
column23: dump every 10 minutes to /tmp/heaps. the second, `hhvm-diff-heaps`, uses
column24: google-pprof to subtract each diff from its successor, which shows where memory
column25: was being allocated in the intervening time between the two dumps.
column27: i tested both shell scripts and linted them with shellcheck.
column30: |move idiosyncratic gdbinit to /home/ori
column33: |provision hhvm source tree in /usr/src instead of /usr/local/src
column35: when i introduced install-pkg-src, the debug symbols for hhvm referenced a
column36: source tree in /home/joe/hhvm/hhvm. more recent packages were built with
column37: /usr/src/hhvm instead. i previously normalized both variants to
column38: /usr/local/src/hhvm using 'set substitute path' in a global gdbinit.
column39: since we're getting rid of that, the simplest way to ensure source code context
column40: is available to gdb is to simply provision the source tree in /usr/src and thus
column41: eliminate the need for source path substitution.

column8: - make logstash inputs resources, not classes. there is no hard reason why

column10: - change logstash::conf resources in role class to use underscores rather than
column11: dashes, which are problematic in puppet resource names.
column12: - move elasticsearch package definitions to a class, elasticsearch::packages,
column13: which can be included multiple times.
column14: - let the elasticsearch package create /etc/elasticsearch, and have
column15: puppet-managed subdirectories depend on the package as a way of ensuring the
column16: parent directory exists.
column17: - rather than a discrete readme file resource, make it part of the conf.d
column19: - rename $config_file variable to $config_name, since it is not the full file
column21: - make logstash::conf depend on conf.d rather than the logstash package.
column22: (the package doesn't create conf.d; we do.)
column23: - leave owner / mode / group unspecified when puppet's defaults will do.
column24: specifying them explicitly makes it seem as though there is some hard reason
column25: why they must be set to these values, when instead the intent is simply for
column26: the files to be uniform with other files in /etc.
column27: - don't use a pointless $config_dir variable when it is hard-coded anyway. it's
column28: easier to reason about manifests if you just have the string literal to stare
column30: - make 'ensure' param first in cases where it was not.
column31: - store "http://${host}:${port}" as $uri var for concision.
column32: - provide a more descriptive comment header for the logstash's init.pp.

column3: for redises in a multi-dc setup, when we switch the replication flow
column4: from one site to the other, the replication flow gets inverted by the
column5: puppet run on the hosts; until they've completed running and puppet has
column6: completed running on the monitoring host we have a discrepancy between
column7: what we're testing for and what we're actually configuring. this results
column8: in a ton of false positives that we want to avoid.
column10: there is no quick and good solution to this, but for now we can live
column11: without the replication lag alarm (we will check it manually around the
column12: time of the switch anyways). it will probably be a wise choice to move
column13: the redis checks to be nrpe checks that can thus be easily modified when
column14: puppet runs on the individual host, and not when it runs on the
column15: monitoring one; however, this hotfix (to be reverted after the
column16: switchback to eqiad is done) will allow us to prevent the alarm spam.

column36: what i propose to do instead is this:

column24: udp2log broke because the kernel parameters it requires were being clobbered.
column25: this is because both sysctl::parameters['big rmem'] and
column26: sysctl::parameters['wikimedia base'] were set to the default priority of 60,
column27: and each was attempting to set net.core.rmem_max to a different value.
column29: in change i50d929847, andrew b. and i fixed things by setting the priority on
column30: sysctl::parameters['big rmem'] to 70. in hindsight, this doesn't go far enough.
column31: we can safely assume that in case of conflict between 'wikimedia base' and some
column32: other sysctl::parameters resource, it's the other resource that should win,
column33: since it is more specific than 'wikimedia base', which specifies cluster-wide
column36: having the default priority set to 60 is unfortunate, because that is the
column37: lowest possible value that is not reserved by debian/ubuntu for sysctl configs
column38: bundled with packages, so it doesn't leave room for declaring broad defaults.
column39: so: make the default 70, and change 'wikimedia base' to 60.
column41: also add documentation and remove the 'filename' parameter from both
column42: sysctl::parameters and sysctl::conffile, since it is both unnecessary and
column43: leaves a way to circumvent the naming convention.
column45: i tested this on vagrant. i also confirmed that integer values are
column46: automatically cast to strings for the purpose of regex matching, so a literal
column47: '70' (the number, not the string) does indeed match /^\d?\d$/.
column50: |add icinga checks for important sysctl params
column52: add 'check_sysctl', an icinga plug-in that issues alerts whenever the actual
column53: and expected values of sysctl parameters are not the same.
column55: i made two additional changes that were prompted by rereading the readme of the
column58: "in general, files in the 10-*.conf range come from the procps package and
column59: serve as system defaults.  other packages install their files in the
column60: 30-*.conf range, to override system defaults.  end-users can use 60-*.conf
column61: and above, or use /etc/sysctl.conf directly, which overrides anything in
column62: this directory."
column66: * make the default priority of sysctl::conffile and sysctl::parameters
column67: resources 60, rather than 10. any additional sysctl::parameters resources
column68: won't come from the procps package itself, so the default priority of 10 is
column69: neither sensible nor safe.
column70: * change priority of sysctl::parameters['lvs'] to 60 so that it conforms with
column71: the priority namespacing policy of the package. (the 50 range is not
column74: change-id: if004835fb369810bba553dce2d2b8df7b8d364ac

column56: |add 'rcstream' module for broadcasting recent changes over websockets
column58: this change introduces an 'rcstream' module, which provisions a small and
column59: self-contained software stack for broadcasting recent changes using websockets.
column60: it is designed to work with the redispubsubfeedengine class in mediawiki.
column62: the setup consists of the following components:
column64: * a single-file python server, powered by gevent and socket.io.
column65: each instance of such server can serve multiple clients concurrently.
column67: * an upstart task (rcstream/init) that spawns multiple instances of this server.
column69: * nginx as load-balancer / reverse proxy. nginx 1.4+ (and therefore, trusty) is
column70: required, as earlier versions are not capable of proxying websocket
column71: connections.
column73: why websockets? admittedly, it is not the world's prettiest protocol. but it is
column74: very widely supported, and it is what users want.
column76: please see the included readme file and the in-line documentation for details
column79: rfcs fulfilled / obsoleted by this change:
column81: * <https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/requests_for_comment/publishing_the_recentchanges_feed>

column3: all of these show up as "top-scope var without namespace" warnings
column4: in puppet-lint.
column6: and in the global puppet-lint.rc we have this comment:
column8: # we still use the 2.6 way of referencing variables
column12: so what i'm doing here is to mark the actual occurences of this
column13: as fixmes and let lint ignore them, but then in turn will remove
column14: that global exception that just turned this off all the time.
column16: that way ci will discourage adding new variables without specific scope.
column18: the existing ones should be fixed, but some cases are easy and some can
column19: be pretty tricky. the ones that are left are mostly of the harder category.
column20: a _lot_ of easy ones have been fixed in the past already,
column21: but for example i remember we tried to fix the one in ganglia before
column22: and it caused problems. so these have to be carefully tested.
column24: we will have to get the fixmes done one by one before puppet 2.8, help

column7: |add 'rcstream' module for broadcasting recent changes over websockets
column9: this change introduces an 'rcstream' module, which provisions a small and
column10: self-contained software stack for broadcasting recent changes using websockets.
column11: it is designed to work with the redispubsubfeedengine class in mediawiki.
column13: the setup consists of the following components:
column15: * a single-file python server, powered by gevent and socket.io.
column16: each instance of such server can serve multiple clients concurrently.
column18: * an upstart task (rcstream/init) that spawns multiple instances of this server.
column20: * nginx as load-balancer / reverse proxy. nginx 1.4+ (and therefore, trusty) is
column21: required, as earlier versions are not capable of proxying websocket
column24: why websockets? admittedly, it is not the world's prettiest protocol. but it is
column25: very widely supported, and it is what users want.
column27: please see the included readme file and the in-line documentation for details
column30: rfcs fulfilled / obsoleted by this change:

column3: change-id: i71dc0694f0d14b7064b8e880529d6c26f3c9f31c
column4: |simplify salt module
column9: reactors can respond immediately to events sent by salt. our
column10: current bootstrapping process in labs for puppet involves a cron
column11: that runs once a minute. by installing salt first, and having salt
column12: run puppet we can more immediately start a puppet run, eliminating
column13: up to one minute of time needed to create an instance.
column15: the reactor chain works like so:
column17: 1. salt requests a certificate -> auth: pend (auth.sls)
column18: 1a. an ldap lookup is performed for the key, if found, it's signed
column19: 2. salt key is signed -> key: accept
column20: 2a. a temporary file is written to the master indicating a first
column21: salt run has not occured yet
column22: 3. the minion's salt process starts -> minion_start
column23: 3a. if puppet hasn't requested a cert, run a command on the minion
column24: requesting a cert and have it fire a puppet: first_run event
column25: 3b. if puppet has request a cert, have the minion fire a

column74: this sets up a separate rsyslog instance that receives messages in
column75: syslog (udp 514) and pipes them to syslog.php.

column79: * the separate instance runs as the librenms user and hence is able to read
column80: the configuration file without giving access to the whole syslog
column81: group.

column83: filtering to avoid logging the local system's logs to librenms.
column84: * the received loglines are only stored in librenms and are not forwarded to
column85: the rest of the syslog config (local log files, remote syslog servers

column3: udp2log broke because the kernel parameters it requires were being clobbered.
column4: this is because both sysctl::parameters['big rmem'] and
column5: sysctl::parameters['wikimedia base'] were set to the default priority of 60,
column6: and each was attempting to set net.core.rmem_max to a different value.
column8: in change i50d929847, andrew b. and i fixed things by setting the priority on
column9: sysctl::parameters['big rmem'] to 70. in hindsight, this doesn't go far enough.
column10: we can safely assume that in case of conflict between 'wikimedia base' and some
column11: other sysctl::parameters resource, it's the other resource that should win,
column12: since it is more specific than 'wikimedia base', which specifies cluster-wide
column15: having the default priority set to 60 is unfortunate, because that is the
column16: lowest possible value that is not reserved by debian/ubuntu for sysctl configs
column17: bundled with packages, so it doesn't leave room for declaring broad defaults.
column18: so: make the default 70, and change 'wikimedia base' to 60.
column20: also add documentation and remove the 'filename' parameter from both
column21: sysctl::parameters and sysctl::conffile, since it is both unnecessary and
column22: leaves a way to circumvent the naming convention.
column24: i tested this on vagrant. i also confirmed that integer values are
column25: automatically cast to strings for the purpose of regex matching, so a literal
column26: '70' (the number, not the string) does indeed match /^\d?\d$/.
column29: |add icinga checks for important sysctl params
column31: add 'check_sysctl', an icinga plug-in that issues alerts whenever the actual
column32: and expected values of sysctl parameters are not the same.
column34: i made two additional changes that were prompted by rereading the readme of the
column37: "in general, files in the 10-*.conf range come from the procps package and
column38: serve as system defaults.  other packages install their files in the
column39: 30-*.conf range, to override system defaults.  end-users can use 60-*.conf
column40: and above, or use /etc/sysctl.conf directly, which overrides anything in
column41: this directory."
column43: thus:
column45: * make the default priority of sysctl::conffile and sysctl::parameters
column46: resources 60, rather than 10. any additional sysctl::parameters resources
column47: won't come from the procps package itself, so the default priority of 10 is
column49: * change priority of sysctl::parameters['lvs'] to 60 so that it conforms with
column50: the priority namespacing policy of the package. (the 50 range is not
column51: defined.)

column63: recursively. this means puppet _will_ purge defaults installed into
column64: /etc/sysctl.d by default. however, the defaults installed by ubuntu precise
column65: have been expressed as sysctl::parameters['ubuntu precise defaults'] in class
column66: base::sysctl.

column27: |sysctl: make the default priority 70
column29: udp2log broke because the kernel parameters it requires were being clobbered.
column30: this is because both sysctl::parameters['big rmem'] and
column31: sysctl::parameters['wikimedia base'] were set to the default priority of 60,
column32: and each was attempting to set net.core.rmem_max to a different value.
column34: in change i50d929847, andrew b. and i fixed things by setting the priority on
column35: sysctl::parameters['big rmem'] to 70. in hindsight, this doesn't go far enough.
column36: we can safely assume that in case of conflict between 'wikimedia base' and some
column37: other sysctl::parameters resource, it's the other resource that should win,
column38: since it is more specific than 'wikimedia base', which specifies cluster-wide
column41: having the default priority set to 60 is unfortunate, because that is the
column42: lowest possible value that is not reserved by debian/ubuntu for sysctl configs
column43: bundled with packages, so it doesn't leave room for declaring broad defaults.
column44: so: make the default 70, and change 'wikimedia base' to 60.
column46: also add documentation and remove the 'filename' parameter from both
column47: sysctl::parameters and sysctl::conffile, since it is both unnecessary and
column48: leaves a way to circumvent the naming convention.
column50: i tested this on vagrant. i also confirmed that integer values are
column51: automatically cast to strings for the purpose of regex matching, so a literal
column52: '70' (the number, not the string) does indeed match /^\d?\d$/.
column55: |add icinga checks for important sysctl params
column57: add 'check_sysctl', an icinga plug-in that issues alerts whenever the actual
column58: and expected values of sysctl parameters are not the same.
column60: i made two additional changes that were prompted by rereading the readme of the
column61: debian procps package:
column63: "in general, files in the 10-*.conf range come from the procps package and
column64: serve as system defaults.  other packages install their files in the
column65: 30-*.conf range, to override system defaults.  end-users can use 60-*.conf
column66: and above, or use /etc/sysctl.conf directly, which overrides anything in
column67: this directory."
column69: thus:
column71: * make the default priority of sysctl::conffile and sysctl::parameters
column72: resources 60, rather than 10. any additional sysctl::parameters resources
column73: won't come from the procps package itself, so the default priority of 10 is
column74: neither sensible nor safe.
column75: * change priority of sysctl::parameters['lvs'] to 60 so that it conforms with
column76: the priority namespacing policy of the package. (the 50 range is not

column4: |icinga: check its own configuration
column6: at the moment, whenever one puppet change breaks the icinga config we
column7: get exactly one puppet failure from neon, which then recovers (as the
column8: icinga config will be reloaded just once), but it seems we can't notice
column9: it promptly. the net effect is that the icinga config is often broken
column10: and it requires me and others to fix it a posteriori when we're doing
column11: another change.
